location: A room in DOCTOR CAIUS' house.

lines.text: Enter MISTRESS QUICKLY, SIMPLE, and RUGBY

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: What, John Rugby! I pray thee, go to the casement, and see if you can see my master, Master Doctor Caius, coming. If he do, i' faith, and find any body in the house, here will be an old abusing of God's patience and the king's English.

lines.speaker: rugby
lines.text: I'll go watch.

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: Go; and we'll have a posset for't soon at night, in faith, at the latter end of a sea-coal fire. An honest, willing, kind fellow, as ever servant shall come in house withal, and, I warrant you, no tell-tale nor no breed-bate: his worst fault is, that he is given to prayer; he is something peevish that way: but nobody but has his fault; but let that pass. Peter Simple, you say your name is?
Exit RUGBY

lines.speaker: simple
lines.text: Ay, for fault of a better.

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: And Master Slender's your master?

lines.speaker: simple
lines.text: Ay, forsooth.

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: Does he not wear a great round beard, like a glover's paring-knife?

lines.speaker: simple
lines.text: No, forsooth: he hath but a little wee face, with a little yellow beard, a Cain-coloured beard.

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: A softly-sprighted man, is he not?

lines.speaker: simple
lines.text: Ay, forsooth: but he is as tall a man of his hands as any is between this and his head; he hath fought with a warrener.

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: How say you? O, I should remember him: does he not hold up his head, as it were, and strut in his gait?

lines.speaker: simple
lines.text: Yes, indeed, does he.

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: Well, heaven send Anne Page no worse fortune! Tell Master Parson Evans I will do what I can for your master: Anne is a good girl, and I wish--
Re-enter RUGBY

lines.speaker: rugby
lines.text: Out, alas! here comes my master.

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: We shall all be shent. Run in here, good young man; go into this closet: he will not stay long. What, John Rugby! John! what, John, I say! Go, John, go inquire for my master; I doubt he be not well, that he comes not home. And down, down, adown-a,  and c.
Shuts SIMPLE in the closet
Singing
Enter DOCTOR CAIUS

lines.speaker: doctor caius
lines.text: Vat is you sing? I do not like des toys. Pray you, go and vetch me in my closet un boitier vert, a box, a green-a box: do intend vat I speak? a green-a box.

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: Ay, forsooth; I'll fetch it you. I am glad he went not in himself: if he had found the young man, he would have been horn-mad.
Aside

lines.speaker: doctor caius
lines.text: Fe, fe, fe, fe! ma foi, il fait fort chaud. Je m'en vais a la cour--la grande affaire.

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: Is it this, sir?

lines.speaker: doctor caius
lines.text: Oui; mette le au mon pocket: depeche, quickly. Vere is dat knave Rugby?

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: What, John Rugby! John!

lines.speaker: rugby
lines.text: Here, sir!

lines.speaker: doctor caius
lines.text: You are John Rugby, and you are Jack Rugby. Come, take-a your rapier, and come after my heel to the court.

lines.speaker: rugby
lines.text: 'Tis ready, sir, here in the porch.

lines.speaker: doctor caius
lines.text: By my trot, I tarry too long. Od's me! Qu'ai-j'oublie! dere is some simples in my closet, dat I vill not for the varld I shall leave behind.

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: Ay me, he'll find the young man here, and be mad!

lines.speaker: doctor caius
lines.text: O diable, diable! vat is in my closet? Villain! larron! Rugby, my rapier!
Pulling SIMPLE out

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: Good master, be content.

lines.speaker: doctor caius
lines.text: Wherefore shall I be content-a?

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: The young man is an honest man.

lines.speaker: doctor caius
lines.text: What shall de honest man do in my closet? dere is no honest man dat shall come in my closet.

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: I beseech you, be not so phlegmatic. Hear the truth of it: he came of an errand to me from Parson Hugh.

lines.speaker: doctor caius
lines.text: Vell.

lines.speaker: simple
lines.text: Ay, forsooth; to desire her to--

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: Peace, I pray you.

lines.speaker: doctor caius
lines.text: Peace-a your tongue. Speak-a your tale.

lines.speaker: simple
lines.text: To desire this honest gentlewoman, your maid, to speak a good word to Mistress Anne Page for my master in the way of marriage.

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: This is all, indeed, la! but I'll ne'er put my finger in the fire, and need not.

lines.speaker: doctor caius
lines.text: Sir Hugh send-a you? Rugby, baille me some paper. Tarry you a little-a while.
Writes

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: [Aside to SIMPLE]  I am glad he is so quiet: if he had been thoroughly moved, you should have heard him so loud and so melancholy. But notwithstanding, man, I'll do you your master what good I can: and the very yea and the no is, the French doctor, my master,--I may call him my master, look you, for I keep his house; and I wash, wring, brew, bake, scour, dress meat and drink, make the beds and do all myself,--

lines.speaker: simple
lines.text: [Aside to MISTRESS QUICKLY]  'Tis a great charge to come under one body's hand.

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: [Aside to SIMPLE]  Are you avised o' that? you shall find it a great charge: and to be up early and down late; but notwithstanding,--to tell you in your ear; I would have no words of it,--my master himself is in love with Mistress Anne Page: but notwithstanding that, I know Anne's mind,--that's neither here nor there.

lines.speaker: doctor caius
lines.text: You jack'nape, give-a this letter to Sir Hugh; by gar, it is a shallenge: I will cut his troat in dee park; and I will teach a scurvy jack-a-nape priest to meddle or make. You may be gone; it is not good you tarry here. By gar, I will cut all his two stones; by gar, he shall not have a stone to throw at his dog:
Exit SIMPLE

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: Alas, he speaks but for his friend.

lines.speaker: doctor caius
lines.text: It is no matter-a ver dat: do not you tell-a me dat I shall have Anne Page for myself? By gar, I vill kill de Jack priest; and I have appointed mine host of de Jarteer to measure our weapon. By gar, I will myself have Anne Page.

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: Sir, the maid loves you, and all shall be well. We must give folks leave to prate: what, the good-jer!

lines.speaker: doctor caius
lines.text: Rugby, come to the court with me. By gar, if I have not Anne Page, I shall turn your head out of my door. Follow my heels, Rugby.
Exeunt DOCTOR CAIUS and RUGBY

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: You shall have An fool's-head of your own. No, I know Anne's mind for that: never a woman in Windsor knows more of Anne's mind than I do; nor can do more than I do with her, I thank heaven.

lines.speaker: fenton
lines.text: [Within]  Who's within there? ho!

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: Who's there, I trow! Come near the house, I pray you.
Enter FENTON

lines.speaker: fenton
lines.text: How now, good woman? how dost thou?

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: The better that it pleases your good worship to ask.

lines.speaker: fenton
lines.text: What news? how does pretty Mistress Anne?

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: In truth, sir, and she is pretty, and honest, and gentle; and one that is your friend, I can tell you that by the way; I praise heaven for it.

lines.speaker: fenton
lines.text: Shall I do any good, thinkest thou? shall I not lose my suit?

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: Troth, sir, all is in his hands above: but notwithstanding, Master Fenton, I'll be sworn on a book, she loves you. Have not your worship a wart above your eye?

lines.speaker: fenton
lines.text: Yes, marry, have I; what of that?

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: Well, thereby hangs a tale: good faith, it is such another Nan; but, I detest, an honest maid as ever broke bread: we had an hour's talk of that wart. I shall never laugh but in that maid's company! But indeed she is given too much to allicholy and musing: but for you--well, go to.

lines.speaker: fenton
lines.text: Well, I shall see her to-day. Hold, there's money for thee; let me have thy voice in my behalf: if thou seest her before me, commend me.

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: Will I? i'faith, that we will; and I will tell your worship more of the wart the next time we have confidence; and of other wooers.

lines.speaker: fenton
lines.text: Well, farewell; I am in great haste now.

lines.speaker: mistress quickly
lines.text: Farewell to your worship. Truly, an honest gentleman: but Anne loves him not; for I know Anne's mind as well as another does. Out upon't! what have I forgot?
Exit FENTON
Exit
